newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada auto union says GM to sell 2 plants.
newsitem.headline: Canada auto union says GM to sell 2 plants.

text.p: The president of the Canadian Auto Workers said on Monday that the union would allow General Motors Corp to sell two of its Canadian parts plants.
Buzz Hargrove told reporters that the Windsor, Ontario trim plant and the Oshawa, Ontario fabrication plant, which employ a total of about 3,400 CAW members, would be put up for sale.
"Windsor trim will be sold," he said.
In answer to a question about the Oshawa fabrication plant, he said, "The same."
Hargrove declined to provide further details.

Talks between the CAW and GM aimed at ending a strike by 26,000 Canadian auto workers are stuck over the union's refusal to accept mandatory overtime at GM's Oshawa factory, Nevertheless, negotiators have said there was enough agreement on other crucial issues, such as outsourcing, to give them confidence that an overall deal could be reached in accordance with a labor agreement pattern that the union set in negotiations with Chrysler Corp last month.
Hargrove said earlier he was hopeful that a deal could be reached today.
GM spokesman Stew Low later confirmed that GM would sell the two plants, but he also told reporters that the workers involved would be covered by the new agreement with the CAW.
